posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked: I was wondering how to utilize pathplanner for autonomous when you have mecanum wheels on your bot. I don’t know how to get pathplanner to recognize you have mecanum wheels or how to program on pathplanner with mecanum wheels. If anyone could please tell me if this is possible and how to do it, it would be very greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Stephen Ostermiller
posts.cooked: Do you have odemetry?  Do you use cameras to look at landmarks such as April tags so that your robot knows where it is on the field?

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked: We do have odometry and we utilize a raspberry Pi camera with photon vision, but we had a recent budget increase so we may be switching to a limelight.

posts.name: Logan Bachman
posts.cooked: PathPlanner’s Autobuilder uses getRobotRelativeSpeeds and driveRobotRelative ( Getting Started | PathPlanner Docs ), it does not care if you are Swerve or Mecanum, if your driveRobotRelative command is doing the correct thing then it should follow a path just like any swerve robot.

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked: Thank you so much! I will try this out and let you know what happens! This would not require any extra programming on my part, correct?

posts.name: Logan Bachman
posts.cooked: Should not require any extra programming assuming your teleop drive command is robot oriented already and it uses ChassisSpeeds as a parameter

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked:
We do not use ChassisSpeeds as a parameter. Here is our drive train code.

How would you recommend implementing ChassisSpeeds as a parameter so that we can utilize pathplanner?

posts.name: Logan Bachman
posts.cooked:
I’m not too familiar with ChassisSpeeds and Mecanum drive but take a look through the WPILib API ( MecanumDrive (WPILib API 2025.3.2) , ChassisSpeeds (WPILib API 2025.3.2) )

Looks like you’ll have to figure out how to get the dx,dy,and dtheta from ChassisSpeeds and input it into your drive command

EDIT: Looks like ChassisSpeeds has vxMetersPerSecond, vyMetersPerSecond, and omegaRadiansPerSecond which can be used and it looks robot relative

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked:
Looking at docs it appears that this variable is only utilized in autonomous correct?

This is the example code provided by first to get chassis Speeds from a field relative. Where or could I insert this into my existing drive train for it to function properly? Also I thought pathplanner handled most of this programming itself and desired angle and mps was calculated by it and not through command based code as mentioned in the example.

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked:
Pathplanner docs states

Blockquote

getPose - Returns the current robot pose as a Pose2d

resetPose - Resets the robot’s odometry to the given pose

getRobotRelativeSpeeds or getCurrentSpeeds - Returns the current robot-relative ChassisSpeeds . This can be calculated using one of WPILib’s drive kinematics classes

driveRobotRelative or drive - Outputs commands to the robot’s drive motors given robot-relative ChassisSpeeds . This can be converted to module states or wheel speeds using WPILib’s drive kinematics classes.

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked: I do not know how to implement all of these values into my drive subsystem for pathplanner to operate.

posts.name: Logan Bachman
posts.cooked:
Your code snippet you shared has the

getPose,

resetPose (resetOdometry),

you need to make a method to get your ChassisSpeeds which MecanumDriveKinematics has a method to return MecanumDriveWheelSpeeds to ChassisSpeeds,

drive which needs the ChassisSpeed, I do not know currently how to take the ChassisSpeeds and use it for driveCartesian right now but I’ll look into and reply with something

posts.name: Logan Bachman
posts.cooked: Found this: allwpilib/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/mecanumbot/Drivetrain.java at main · wpilibsuite/allwpilib Look at the setSpeeds method and modify it to take in ChassisSpeeds instead of MecanumDriveWheelSpeeds since PathPlanner requires ChassisSpeeds and MecanumDriveWheelSpeeds has a method to convert ChassisSpeeds to MecanumDriveWheelSpeeds here: MecanumDriveKinematics (WPILib API 2025.3.2)

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked:
If you already have your odometry setup and localization with Photon Vision, then the only thing you’re missing is a PID Tuned Drivetrain.

PathPlanner will supply you with Chassis Speeds, they’re in Meters Per Second. So in order to drive properly you will need to be able to tell your robot how to drive at those speeds. You can do that through PID Tuning.

If your drive is already tuned then it should be somewhat straight forward to implement. Though it’s my understanding that your pose estimation might be your biggest hurdle, making sure your Localization and Odometry are accurate are required for PathPlanner to work.

I’m speaking from experience as we used Mecanum last year and were unable to get PathPlanner working, but this year we’re running swerve and using PathPlanner so lmk if you have any questions!

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked: How would I tune my drive train using PID ? My drive subsystem code is published above if you need it

posts.name: Alexander Carlisi
posts.cooked:
Sources: WPILib

To start you need to understand what it is, I suggest reading the docs I reference above.

Here you want to tune your motors voltage to produce the output of velocity that you want. So the first thing that you need to do is get velocity from your motor.

I can see your getSpeeds method is returning a blank MecanumWheelSpeeds. You can get the speed of your motors by using an Encoder. I see you have a brushless Sparkmax, so if you’re using Neo motors they have a Hall-effect internal encoder built in, you should be able to call it using neo.getEncoder()

The encoder should have a getRate method, this will return the change in your encoders rotations, it should be in rotation/second, so you will need to convert it into Meters per second.

From there you should create Feedforward and PIDControllers for each motor, and follow WPILibs PID tuning a fly wheel for the steps on that.

If you need any more clarification let me know!
